editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: No-body, and some-body¨ With the true chronicle historie of Elydure, who was fortunately three seuerall times crowned King of England. The true coppy thereof, as it hath beene acted by the Queens Maiesties Seruants.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed [by James Roberts] for Iohn Trundle and are to be sold at his shop in Barbican, at the signe of No-body,

note.p: Printer's name and publication date from STC.
The first leaf is blank. The last leaf verso has a woodcut with caption: Some-body.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.p: Nobody, and somebody. With the true chronicle history of Elydure, who was fortunately three several times crowned King of England. The true copy thereof, as it hath been acted by the Queen's majesty's servants.
Printed for John trundle and are to be sold at his shop in Barbican, at the sign of nobody.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: A subject, of no subject, we present, for nobody, is nothing:
Who of nothing can something make?
It is a work beyond the power of wit,
A moral meaning you must then expect, grounded on lesser than a shadow's shadow:
Promising nothing where there wants a tongue;
And deeds as few, be done by nobody:
Yet something, out of nothing, we will show,
To gain your loves, to whom ourselves we owe.

div.head: Nobody, and somebody.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: My lord Martianus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My lord of Cornwell.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Morrow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Morrow,

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: You are sad my lord.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You melancholy.

sp.speaker: Corne.
sp.l: So,
The state itself mourns in a robe of woe.

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.l: For the decease of Archigallo's virtues,
I understand you noble minded Cornwell,
What generous spirit draws this British air,
But droops at Archigallo's government.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: And reason Martianus, when the sun
Struggles to be delivered from the womb
Of an obscure eclipse, doth not the earth
Mourn to behold his shine enveloped,
Oh Corbonon when I did close thine eyes,
I gave release to Britain's miseries.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good morrow to prince Elydure.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: The same to you, and you, you are sad my lords,
Your hearts I think are frosty, for your blood
Seems crusted in your faces, like the dew
In a September morn, how fares the King,
Have you yet bid good morrow to his highness.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: The Kings not stirring yet.

sp.speaker: Perid
sp.l: Yonder's old Cornwell, come Vïgenius,
We'll have some sport with him:

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Brother content.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Good morrow to you brother Elydure.

sp.speaker: Cornwel,
sp.p: Good morrow to Cornwell.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Morrow old graybeard.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: My beards not so grey as your wits green.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: And why so.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: We shall ha' you come out now with some reason that was born in my great grand sire's time.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Would you would prove as honest princes as your great grandsire was, or half so wise as your elder brother was, there's a couple of you, sfoot I am ashamed you should be of the blood royal.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: And why father winter.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: You do not know your state, there's Elydure
Your elder brother next unto the King,
He plies his book, when shall you see him trace
Lascivious Archigallo through the streets,
And fight with common hackster's hand to hand,
To wrest from them their goods and dignities.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: You are too saucy Cornwell.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Bridle your spirit.

sp.speaker: Elyd.
sp.l: Your words are dangerous, good honest subject
Old reverent statesman, faithful servitor,
Do not traduce the King, he's virtuous
Or say he tread somewhat besides the line
Of virtuous government, his regality
Brooks not taxation, King's greatest royalties
Are that their subjects must applaud their deeds,
As well as bear them their prerogatives.
Are mural interponents twixt the world,
And their proceedings.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Well, well, I have served four Kings,
And none of all those four but would have ventured
Their safeties on old Cornwall's constancy,
But that's all one, now I am called a dotard,
Go to, though now my limbs be stark and stiff,
When Cornwall's dead Britain I know will want
so strong a prop, alas I needs must weep,
And shed tears in abundance, when I think
How Archigallo wrongs his government.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Nay, now you'll fall into your tetchy humour.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: My lords, princes I should have said, and after
Lords, I am the usher and harbinger unto the Kings most
Excellent person and his majesty.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Is fourth coming.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: Or coming fourth, hard by or at hand, will you put your gestures of attendance on, to give his majesty the bonjour.

div.stage: Enter Archigallo and two lords. Morgan Malgo.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Good morrow to our sovereign Archigallo.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Morrow.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Why do you frown upon your servant's King,
We love you, and you ought to favour us:
Will you to counsel. Here's petitions,
Complaints and controversies twixt your subjects,
Appealing all to you.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Let's see those papers. A controversy betwixt the lord Morgan and the lord Malgo, concerning their titles to the Southern island. We know this cause and what their titles be. You claim it by inheritance.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.p: My liege I do.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: You by the marriage of lord Morgan's mother,
To whom it was left jointure.

sp.speaker: Malgo.
sp.p: True gracious sovereign.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Whose evidence is strongest, to which part
Inclines the censures of our learned judges.

sp.speaker: Morgan.
sp.l: We come not here to plead before your grace,
But humbly to entreat your majesty,
Peruse our evidence and censure it,
According to your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: What I determine then you'll yield unto.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We will my sovereign.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Then that Southern I'll
We take to our protection, and make you
Lord governor thereof.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: I humbly thank your highness.

sp.speaker: M●l.
sp.p: I hope your majesty.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Reply not, I but take it to myself
Because I would not have dissension
Betwixt two peers, I love to see you friends,
And now the islands mine, your quarrel ends.
What's next. A poor Northern man's humble petition.
Which is the plaintive?

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: I if it please your majesty I was betrothed to this maid.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Is this true my wench.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: 'Tis very true and like your majesty, but this tempting fellow after that, most feloniously stole my heart away from me, carried it into the church, and I running after him to get my heart again, was there married to this other man.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: 'Tis very true and like your majesty, though Raphe were once look for a proper man, yet when I came in place it appeared otherwise: if your highness note his leg and mine, there is odds, and for a foot, I dare compare, I have a waist to, and though I say it, that should not say it there are faces in place of god's making.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Thou art a proper fellow, and this wench is thine by lawful marriage.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Rafe you have your answer, you may be gone, your only way to save charges, is to buy a half-pennyworth of hobnails for your shoes: alas you might have looked into this before, go silly Rafe go, away, vanish.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Is not this lass a pretty neat brown wrench?

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: She is my liege, and mettle I dare warrant.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Fellow, how long hast thou been married?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I was as they say coupled the same day that my country man Raphe begun the law: for to tell your majesty the truth, we are yet both virgins, it did never freeze betwixt us two in a bed I assure your grace.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Didst never lie with thy wife?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Never yet, but now your majesty hath ended the matter I'll be so bold as take possession.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Hark my wench, wilt leave these rustic fellows and stay with me?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: What will your highness do with me?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Why I'll make thee a lady.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: And shall I go in fine clothes like a lady.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: I'll be a lady then, that's flat, sweet heart farewell, I must be a lady, so I must.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: How now, how now, but hear you sir.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Away you clown, away.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But will your highness rob me of my spouse.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: What we will, we will, away with those slaves.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Zounds, if ever I take you in Yorkshire for this.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: Away you slaves.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: My lord, these general wrongs will draw your highness into the common hatred of your subjects.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: What's that to thee, old doting lord forbear.
What's here? complaints against one nobody,
For overmuch relieving of the poor,
Helping distressed prisoners, entertaining
Extravagants and vagabonds, what fellows this?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: My liege I know him, he's an honest subject
That hates extortion, usury, and such sins
As are too common in this land of Britain.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: I'll have none such as he within my kingdom,
He shall be banished.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Hear my advice my liege: I know a fellow
that's opposite to nobody in all things:
As he affects the poor, this other hates them,
Loves usury and extortion. Send him straight
Into the country, and upon my life,
Ere many months he will devise some means
To make that nobody bankrupt, make him fly
His country, and be never heard of more.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: What dost thou call his name.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: His name is somebody my liege.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Seek out that somebody, we'll send him straight,
What other matters stay to be decided
Determine you, and you, the rest may follow
To give attendance.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: All's naught already, yet these unripe ills
Have not their full growth, and their next degree
Must needs be worse than naught, and by what name
Do you call that?

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: I know none bad enough:
Base, vild, notorious, ugly monstrous, slavish,
Intolerable, abhorred, damnable;
'Tis worse than bad, I'll be no longer vassal
To such a tyrannous rule, nor accessary
To the base sufferance of such outrages.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: You'll not endure it, how can you remedy
A maim so dangerous and incurable?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: There is a way; but walls have ears and eyes,
Your ear my lord, and counsel.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I have ears
Open to such discourse, and counsel apt:
And to the full recovery of these wounds
Made in the sick state, most effectual,
A word in private.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Come brother, I am tired with revelling,
My last coranto made me almost breathless,
Doth not the Kings last wench foot it with art?

sp.speaker: Vige.
sp.l: O rarely, rarely, and beyond opinion.
I like this state where all are libertines
But by ambition's pleasure and large will:
See, see, two of our strict lived counsellors
In secret conference; they cannot endure
This freedom.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Nor the rule of Archigallo,
Because 'tis subject to his liberty.
Are they not plotting now for some instalment
And change of state: old gallants if you be
'Twill cost your heads.

sp.speaker: Vige.
sp.l: Bodies and all for me.
List them, such strict reprovers should not live,
Their austere censures on their Kings to give.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: He must be then deposed.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Ay, are you there, that word sounds treason.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Nay, but farther hear.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: The King deposed, how must it be effected,
What strengths and powers can suddenly be levied,
Who will assist this business, to reduce
The state to better form and government?

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Ay marry, more of that.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: All cornwells at my beck, Devonshire our neighbour
Is one with us, you in the North command.
The oppressed, wronged, dejected and suppressed,
Will flock on all sides to this innovation:
The clergy late despised, the nobles scorned,
The commons trodden on, and the law contemned,
Will lend a mutual and combined power
Unto this happy change.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: O monstrous treason!

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: My lord, we are betrayed, and overheard
By the two princes.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: How, betrayed.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Our plots discovered.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I'll help it all; do you but sooth me up,
We'll catch them in the trap they lay for us.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Now sir, the King deposed
Who shall succeed?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Some would say Elidure.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Tush, he's too mild to rule.
But there are two young princes, hopeful youths
And of rare expectation in the land,
O would they deign to bear this weighty charge
Betwixt them, and support the regal sceptre
With joint assistance, all our hopes were full.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: A sceptre.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: And a crown.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: What if we made the motion? we have wills
To effect it, we have power to compass it.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: And if I make refusal, heaven refuse me.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: These counsellors are wise, and see in us
More virtue than we in ourselves discern.
Would it were come to such election.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: My honoured lord, we'll break it to those princes,
Those hopeful youths, at our convenient leisure.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: You that our footsteps watched,
Shall in the depth of your own wiles be caught.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: A King.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: And were a crown, a crown imperial.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: And sit in state.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Command.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: And be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Our nobles kneeling.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Servant's homaging, and crying aue.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: O brother, shall we through nice folly
Despise the proffered bounty of these lords?

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Not for the world, I long to sit in state,
To purse the bounty of our gracious fate.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: To entertain foreign ambassadors.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: And have our names ranked in the course of Kings.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Shadow us state with thy majestic wings.

div.stage: Enter King, Cornwell, Martianus, and Elidure.

sp.speaker: Vige.
sp.p: Now sir, my brother Archigall deposed

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Deposed! did you hear that my lord.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: For his licentious rule, and such abuses
As we'll pretend 'gainst him in parliament.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: O monstrous brothers.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.p: O ambitious youths.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Thus we'll divide the land, all beyond Trent
And Humber, shall suffice one moiety:
The South part of the land shall make the tother,
Where we will keep two courts, and reign divided,
Yet as dear loving brothers.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: As vild traitors.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Then Archigall, thou that hast sat in pomp
And seen me vassal, shalt behold me crowned,
Whilst thou with humble knees vail'st to my state.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: And when must this be done, when shall my crown
Be parted and divided into halves.
You reign on this side Humber, you beyond
The river Trent, when do you take your states,
Sit crowned and sceptred to receive our homage,
Our duty, and our humble vassalage.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: I know not when.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Nor you?

sp.speaker: Vige.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: But I know when you shall repent your pride.
Nor will we use delays in our revenge,
Ambitious boys, we doom you prisonment,
Your palace royal shall a jail be made,
Your thrones a dungeon, and your sceptres irons,
In which we'll bound your proud aspiring thoughts:
A way with them, we will not mount our chair
Till their best hopes be changed to black despair.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Hear us excuse ourselves.

sp.speaker: Vige.
sp.l: Or let's discover
Who drew us to this hope of sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: That shall our further leisures arbitrate,
Our ears are deaf to all excusive pleas,
Come unambitious brother Elidurus,
Help us to lavish our abundant treasures,
In masks, sports, revels, riots, and strange pleasures.

div.stage: Enter somebody with two or three servants.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: But is it true the fame of nobody,
For virtue, almsdeeds, and for charity,
Is so renowned and famous in the country?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: O lord sir ay, he's talked of far and near,
Fills all the boundless country with applause,
There lives not in all Britain one so spoke of,
For pity, good mind, and true charity.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Which somebody shall alter ere't be long.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You may my lord being in grace at court,
And the high favours of King Archigallo
Exile this petty fellow from the land,
That so obscures the beauty of your deeds.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: What doth this nobody?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: You shall hear my lord,
come twenty poor men to his gate at once,
Nobody gives them money, meat and drink,
If they be naked, clothes, then come poor soldiers,
Sick, maimed, and shot, from any foreign wars,
Nobody takes them in, provides them harbour,
Maintains their ruind fortunes at his charge,
He gives to orphans, and for widows builds
Almshouses, spitals, and large hospitals,
And when it comes in question, who is apt
For such good deeds, 'tis answered nobody.
Now nobody hath entertained again
Long banished hospitality, and at his board
A hundred lusty yeomen daily waits,
Whose long backs bend with weighty chines of beef,
And choice of cheer, whose fragments at his gate
Suffice the general poor of the whole shire.
Nobody's table's free for travellers,
His buttery and his seller open to all
That starve with drought, or thirst upon the way,

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: His fame is great, how should we help it?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord, 'tis passed my reach, 'tis you must do it,
Or't must be left undone.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: What deeds of note is he else famous for?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord I'll tell you.
His barns are full, and when the cormorants
And wealthy farmers hoard up all the grain,
He empties all his garners to the poor
Under the stretched prize that the market yields,
Nobody racks no rends, doth not oppress
His tenants with extortions. When the King
Knighted the lusty gallants of the land,
Nobody then made dainty to be knighted,
And indeed kept him in his known estate.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: The slaves ambitious ▪ and his life I hate.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: How shall we bring his name in public scandal?

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Thus it shall be, use my direction.
In court and country I am somebody,
And therefore apt and fit to be employed:
Go thou in secret being a subtle knave.
And sow seditious slanders through the land,
Oppress the poor, suppress the fatherless,
Deny the widow's food, the starved relief,
And when the wretches shall complain their wrongs,
Being called in question, swear 'twas nobody,
Rack rends, raise prizes,
Buy up the best and choice commodities
At the best hand, then keep them till their prizes
Be lifted to their height, and double rate,
And when the raisers of this dearth are sought
Though somebody do this, protest and swear
'Twas nobody fore judge and magistrate:
Bring scandals on the rich, raise mutinous lies
Upon the state, and rumours in the court,
Backbite and sow dissension amongst friends,
Quarrels amongst neighbours, and debate amongst strangers,
Set man and wife at odds, kindred at strife,
And when it comes in question, to clear us,
Let every one protest and swear for one,
And so the blame will fall on nobody.
About it then, if these things well succeed,
You shall prevail, and we applaud your speed.
See where he comes, I will withdraw and see,
The event and fortunes of our last policy.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.p: Come on mine own servant, some news, some news, what report have I in the country? how am I talked on in the city, and what fame bear I in the court?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: O master you are half hanged.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.p: Hanged, why man?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Because you have an ill name: a man had as good almost serve no master as serve you, I was carried afore the constable but yesterday, and they took me up for a stravagant; they asked me whom I served, I told them nobody, they presently drew me to the post, and there gave me the law of arms.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: The law of arms.

sp.speaker: Clow,
sp.p: Ay, as much law as their arms were able to lay on, they tickled my collifodium, I rid post for a quarter of an hour, with switch though not with spur.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.p: Sure somebody was the cause of all.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I'll be sworn of that, somebody tickled me a heat, and that I felt, but master, why do you go thus out of fashion; you are even a very hoddy-doddy , all breech,

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.p: And nobody . But if my breeches had as much cloth in them, as ever was drawn betwixt Kendall and Canning street, they were scarce great enough to hold all the wrongs that I must pocket:
sp.l: Fie, fie, how I am slandered through the world.
Nobody keeps tall fellows at his heels,
Yet if you meet a crew of rogues and beggars,
Ask who they serve, they'll answer nobody.
Your cavaliers and swaggerers bout the town,
That domineer in taverns, swear and stare,
Urge them upon some terms, they'll turn their malice
To me, and say they'll fight with nobody,
Or if they fight, and nobody by chance
Come in to part them, I am sure to pay for it,
And nobody be hurt when they scape scotfree:
And not the dastardst coward in the world
But dares about with me. What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Do what thou wilt, before we end this strife,
I'll make thee ten times weary of thy life.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But do you hear master, when I have served you a year or two, who shall pay me my wages?

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: Why nobody.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Indeed if I serve nobody, nobody must pay me my wages, therefore I'll even seek out somebody or other, to get me a new service; but the best is master if you run away, you are easy to be found again.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.p: Why so sir?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Marry ask a deaf man whom he hears, he'll straight say nobody, ask the blindest beetle that is whom he sees, and he'll answer, nobody, he that never saw in his life can see you, though you were as little as a moat, and he that never heard, can hear you, though you tread as softly as a mouse, therefore I shall be sure never to lose you. Besides, you have one commodity master, which none hath besides you, if you should love the most fickle and inconstant'st wench that is in the world, she'll be true to nobody, therefore constant to you.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.l: And thou sayest true in that my honest servant,
Besides, I am in great especial grace
With the King Archigallo that now reigns
In tyranny, and strange misgovernment,
Nobody loves him, and he loves nobody.
But that which most torments my troubled soul,
My name is made mere opposite to virtue,
For he is only held peaceful and quiet,
That quarrels, brawls, and fights with nobody,
He's honest held that lies with nobody's wife,
And he that hurts and injures nobody,
All the world says, ay that's a virtuous man.
And though a man have done a thousand mischiefs,
And come to prove the forfeit made to law,
If he can prove he hath wronged nobody,
No man can touch his life. This makes me mad,
This makes me leave the place where I was bred,
And thousand times a day to wish me dead.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: And I'll pursue thee wheresoe'er thou fliest,
Nor shalt thou rest in England till thou diest.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Master, I would wish you to leave the country, and see what good entertainment you will have in the city, I do not think but there you will be most kindly respected, I have been there in my youth, there's hospitality, and you talk of hospitality, and they talk of you abomination to see: for there master come to them as often as you will, four times a day, and they'll make nobody drink, they love to have nobody trouble them, and without good security they will lend nobody money. Come into Birchin lane, they'll give nobody a suit, choose where he list; go into Cheapside, and nobody may take up as much plate as he can carry.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.l: Then I'll to London, for the country tires me
With exclamations, and with open wrongs,
Sith in the city they affect me so.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: O master, there I am sure nobody may have any thing without money, nobody may come out of the tavern without paying his reckoning at his pleasure.

div.stage: Enter a man meeting his wife.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: That's better than the country. Who comes here?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Minion, where have you been all this night?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Why do you ask husband?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Because I would know wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I have been with nobody.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.p: 'Tis a lie good man, believe her not, she was not with me.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: And who hath lain with you tonight ?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Lie with me, why nobody.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.p: O monstrous, they would make me a whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Well, I do not think but somebody hath been with you.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Somebody was indeed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: God's life husband, you do me wrong, I lay with nobody.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Well minion, though nobody bear the blame,
Use it no more, lest somebody bide the shame.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.l: I will endure no longer in this climate
it is so full of slanders, I'll to the city,
And there perform the deeds of charity.

div.stage: Enter the 2 man and a prentice.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: Now you rascal, who have you been withal at the alehouse?

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Sooth I was with nobody.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.p: Not with me.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: And who was drunk there with you?

sp.speaker: Prentice
sp.p: Sooth nobody was drunk with me.

sp.speaker: Nobod.
sp.l: O intolerable! they would make me a drunkard to,
I cannot endure any longer, I must hence,
No patience with such scandals can dispense.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.l: Well sirrah, if I take you so again, I'll so belabour you:
Oh neighbour good morrow.

sp.speaker: 1 man.
sp.p: Good morrow,

sp.speaker: 2 Man
sp.p: You are sad methinks ,

sp.speaker: 1 Man
sp.p: Faith sir I have cause, I have lent a friend of mine a hundred pound, and have nobody's word for the payment, bill, nor bond, nor any thing to show.

sp.speaker: 2 man.
sp.p: Have you nobody's word, I'll assure you that nobody is a good man, a good man I assure you neighbour, nobody will keep his word, nobody's word is as good as his bond.

sp.speaker: 1 Man
sp.l: Ay, say you so, nay then let's drink down sorrow,
If none would lend, than nobody should borrow.

sp.speaker: Nobody
sp.l: Yet there's one keeps a good tongue in his head,
That can give nobody a good report,
I am beholding to him for his praise:
But since my man so much commends the city,
I'll thither, and to purchase me a name,
Take a large house of infinite receipt,
There keep a table for all good spirits,
And all the chimneys shall cast smoke at once:
There I'll give scholars pensions, poet's gold,
Arts their deserts, philosophy due praise,
learning his merit, and all worth his meed.
There I'll release poor prisoners from their dungeons.
Pay creditors the debts of other men,
And get myself a name amongst citizens,
That after times partakers of all bliss,
May thus record, nobody did all this.
Country farewell, whose slanderous tongues I sly,
The city now shall lift my name on high.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Whether I'll follow thee with swallows wings,
And nimble expedition, there to raise
New brawls and rumours to eclipse thy praise.
Those subtle, sly insinuating fellows
Whom somebody hath sent into the country,
To rack, transport, extort, and to oppress,
Will I call home, and all their wits employ
Against this public benefactor, known
Honest, for all the rumours by us sown.
But howsoever, I am sworn his foe,
And opposite to all his meriting deeds,
This way must do, though my divining thoughts
This augury amidsts their changes have,
That somebody will at length be proved a knave.

div.stage: Enter Queen, sycophant, and lady Elidure severally.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Good day to you both fair ladies,
But fairest of them both my gracious Queen,
Good day to your high majesty, and madam
The royal lady of great Elidure,
My sovereign's brother, unto you I wish
This morning prove as gracious and as good.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Those greetings from the lady Elidure
Would pleasingly sound in our princely ears.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Such greetings from great Archigallo's Queen
would be most gracious to our princely ear.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What no good morrow and our grace so near.
Reach me my glove.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Whom speaks this woman to?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Why to my subject, to my waiting maid,
Am not I mighty Archigallo's Queen?
Is not my lord the royal English King,
Thy husband and thyself my servitors?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Is my coach ready, where are all my men
That should attend upon our awful frown,
What not one near?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Minion, my glove.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: Madam, her highness glove.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My scarf is fallen, one of you reach it up.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: You hear me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Painted majesty be gone,
I am not to be counterchecked by any.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Shall I bear this?

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Be patient, I will school her.
Your excellence greatly forgets yourself
To be so dutiless unto the Queen,
I have seen the world, I know what 'tis to obey,
And to command. What if it please the Queen
That you her subject should attend on her,
And take her glove up, is it meet that I
Should stoop for yours? You're proud, fie, fie, you're proud.
This must not be twixt such two royal sisters
As you by marriage are; go to submit,
Her majesty is easy to forgive.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Saucy lord forbear, there's for your exhortation.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I cannot bear this, 'tis insufferable,
I'll to the King, and if he save thy life
He shall have mine: madness and wrath attend,
My thoughts are levelled at a bloody end.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: She's shadow,
we the true substance are: follow her those
That to our greatness dare themselves oppose.

div.stage: Enter Cornwell, Martianus, Morgan and Malgo.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: Health to your ladyship, I would say Queen
If I might have my mind, by'r lady lady.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I had a suit unto the King with this lord
For the great office of high seneschal,
Because of our good service to the state,
But he in scorn, as he doth every thing,
Hath ta'en it from us both, and gin't a fool.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.p: To a sycophant, a courtly parasite.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Bear witness madam, I'll go tell the King
That they speak treason.

sp.speaker: Malgo.
sp.l: Pass upon our swords,
You old exchecker of all flattery,
I tell thee Archigallo shall be deposed,
And thou disrobed of all thy dignity.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: I hope not so.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: See here the counsel's hands,
Subscribed to Archigallo's overthrow.
The names of sixteen royal English peers,
Joined in a league that is inviolate,
And nothing wants but Elidurus' grant
To accept the kingdom when the deed is done.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: Nay then I'll take your parts, and join with you ▪

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: We will not have a clawbacks hand commixed
With such heroic peers.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: I hope my lady
Is not of their minds. My most gracious Queen,
What I did speak in reprehensive sort,
Was more because her majesty was present
Then any offence of yours, and so esteem it,
God knows I love your highness, and these lords.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Which of you will persuade my Elidure
To take upon him England's royalty.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Madam, we all have so importuned him,
Laying unto his judgement every thing
That might attract his senses to the crown,
But he frost brained will not be obtained
To take upon him this realm's government.

sp.speaker: Malg.
sp.l: He is the very soul of lenity,
If ever moderation lived in any,
Your lord with that rich virtue is possessed.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: This mildness in him makes me so despised
By the proud Queen, and by her favourites.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.p: See madam where he comes reading a book.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My lord and husband, with your leave this book
Is fitter for an university
Then to be looked on, and the crown so near:
You know these lords for tyranny have sworn
To banish Archigallo from the throne,
And to invest you in the royalty:
Will you not thank them, and with bounteous hands
Sprinkle their greatness with the names of Earls,
Dukes, marquesses, and other higher terms.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: My dearest love, the essence of my soul,
And you my honoured lords, the suit you make,
Though it be just for many wrongs imposed,
Yet unto me it seems an injury.
What is my greatness by my brother's fall,
But like a starved body nourished
With the destruction of the other limbs.
Innumerable are the griefs that wait
On hoarded treasures, then much more on crowns:
The middle path, the golden mean for me,
Leave me obedience, take you majesty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why this is worser to my lofty mind,
Than the late checks given by the angry Queen.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: If you refuse it, know we are determined
To lay it else where.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: On your younger brother,
And then no doubt we shall be awed indeed,
When the ambition of the elders wife,
Can scarcely give our patience any bounds:
England is sick of pride and tyranny,
And in thy goodness only to be cured.
Thou art called forth amongst a thousand men,
To minister this sovereign antidote,
To amend thy brother's cruelty with love,
And if thou wilt not from oppression free
Thy native country, thou art vild as he.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: I had rather stay his leisure to amend.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Men, heaven, gods, devils, what power should I invoke,
To fashion him a new: thunder come down,
Crown me with ruin, since not with a crown.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: Long life unto the kingly Elidure,
Trumpets proclaim it whether he will or no.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For that conceit lords, you have won my heart,
In his despite let him be straight ways crowned,
That I may triumph whilst the trumpets sound.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: Carry me to my grave, not to a throne.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Help lords to seat him, nay help every one:
So should the majesty of England sit,
Whilst we in like state do associate him.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: Never did any less desire to reign
Then I, heaven knows this greatness is my pain.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pain me in this sort great lords every day,
'Tis sweet to rule.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: 'Tis sweeter to obey.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: Live King of England long and happily,
As long and happily your highness live.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: We thank you lords, now call in the deposed,
Him and his proud Queen, bring unto our sight,
That in her wrongs we may have our delight.

div.stage: Enter Archigallo, and his Queen bound.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: Betrayed, ta'en prisoner, and by those that owe
To me their duty, and allegiance:
My brother the usurper of the crown,
O this is monstrous, most insufferable.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: Good brother grieve not, 'tis against my will,
That I am made a King, pray take my place,
I had rather be your subject than your lord.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: So had not I, sit still my gracious lord,
Whilst I look through this tyrant with a frown,
Minion reach up my glove.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thinkst thou because
Thy husband can dissemble piety,
And therein hath deposed my royal lord,
That I am lesser in estate than Queen?
No thine own answer lately given to me,
I thus revet, stoop thou proud Queen for me.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Nay, then as I did lately to her highness,
I must admonish you, diected lady
You do forget yourself, and where you are,
Duty is debt, and it is fit since now
You are a subject, to bear humble thoughts:
Follow my counsel lady and submit,
Her majesty no doubt will pardon it.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: There's for your pains.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Which way soe'er I go,
I have it here, whether it ebb or flow.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That pride of thine shall be thy overthrow.
And thus I sentence them.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: Leave that to me?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No you are too mild, judgement belongs to me:
thou Archigallo for thy tyranny,
For ever be excluded from all rule,
And from thy life.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: Not from his life I pray.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He unto whom the greatest wrongs are done,
Dispatch him quickly.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.p: That will I.

sp.speaker: Maglo.
sp.p: Or I.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: And therein lords effect my tragedy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why strike you not, o 'tis a dangerous thing,
To have a living subject of a King:
Much treason may be wrought, when in his death,
Our safety is secured.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: Banish him rather, o sweet spare his life,
He is my brother.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.p: Crowned, and pray thy wife.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: O brother, if you roughly speak, I know
There is no hope but your sure overthrow,
Pray be not angry with me for my love:
To banishment since it must needs be so,
His life I give him whosoe'er says no.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What and his ladies to.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: I hers and all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But I'll not have you banished with the King,
No minion no, since you must live, be assured
I'll make thee meanest of my waiting maids.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I scorn thy pride.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: Farewell deceiving state,
Pride making crown, my dearest wife farewell:
I have been a tyrant, and I'll be so still.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: Alas my brother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Dry up childish tears,
And to these lords that have invested you,
Give gracious looks, and honourable deeds.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: Give them my crown, o give them all I have,
thy throne I reckon but a glorious grave.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Then from myself these dignities receive,
The island wrested from you I restore,
See it be given them back lord sycophant.
The office of high seneschal bereft you,
My lord of Cornwell to your grace we give.
You Martianus be our treasurer,
And if we find you faithful, be assured
You shall not want preferment at our hands.
Mean time this office we impose on you,
Be tutor to this lady, and her pride
With your learnd principles whereof you are full
Turn to humility, or vex her soul,

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Torment on torment, tutored by a fool.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: Madam, it is her highness will be pleased.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Young Peridurus and Vigenius, lords
Release from prison, and because your King,
Is mightily affected unto York,
Thither dismiss the court incontinent.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: Shall it be so my liege.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Are not we King.
His silence says it, and what we ordain,
Who dares make question of: this day for ever
Through our reign beheld a festival:
And triumph lords that England is set free,
From a vild tyrant and his cruelty:

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: On to our funeral, 'tis no matter where,
I sin I know in suffering pride so near.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: Ahem boy, nobody is sound yet for all his troubles.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
And so is nobody's man for all his whipping, but master we are now in the city, walled about from slander, there cannot a lie come in but it must run through brick, or get the goodwill of the warders, whose brown bills look blue upon
all passengers.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: O this city, if nobody live to be as old again, be it spoken in secret, I'll have fenced about with a wall of brass.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Of nobody's making, that will be rare.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: I'll bring the Thames through the middle of it, empty More-ditch at my own charge, and build up Paul's-steeple without a collection. I see not what becomes of these collections.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why nobody receives them.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: I knave?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: You knave: or as the world goes, somebody receives all, and nobody is blamed for it.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: But is it rumoured so through out the city.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Do not you know that? there's not an orphans portion lost out of the chamber, but nobody has got it, no corn transported without warrant, but nobody has done it, no goods stolen but by nobody, no extortion without nobody: and but that truth will come to light, few wenches got with child, but with nobody.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: Nay that's by somebody.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I think somebody had a hand in't, but nobody sometimes pays for the nursing of it.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: Indeed I have taken into my charge many a poor infant left to the alms of the wide world, I have helped many a virtuous maid to a good husband, and ne'er desired her maidenhead: redeemed many gentlemen's lands, that have thanked nobody for it, built pest-houses, and other places of retirement in the sickness time for the good of the city, and yet nobody cannot get a good word for his labour.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: 'Tis a mad world master.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.l: Yet this mad world shall not make me mad, I am
All spirit, nobody let them grieve,
That scrape for wealth I will the poor relieve,
Where are the masters of the several prisons:
Within and near adjoining to the city,
That I may spread my charity abroad.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Here they be sir.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.l: Welcome gentlemen:
You are they that make poor men householders
Against their wills, and yet do them no wrong:
You have the actions, and the cases of your sides,
Whilst your tenants in common, want money to fill them.
How many gentlemen of less revenues than nobody,
Lie in your knight's ward, for want of maintenance.

sp.p: I am sir a keeper of the counter, and there are in our wards above a hundred poor prisoners, that are like never to come forth without satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: But nobody will be their benefactor. What in yours.
As many as in the other prison.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: There's to release them. What in yours.
Double the number, and in the jail.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: Talk not of the jail, 'tis full of lime-twigs, lifts, and pickpockets.
Is it your pleasure sir to free them all.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: All that he in for debt.
Ten thousand pound, and ten to that will not do it.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.l: Nobody sir will give a hundred thousand,
Ten hundred thousand, nobody will not have a prisoner,
Because they all shall pray for nobody.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: 'Tis great pity my master has nobody, and so kind a heart.

div.stage: A noise within. Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: What outcries that?

div.stage: Enter somebody, with two or three.

sp.speaker: Somebody.
sp.l: That is the gallant, apprehend him straight,
'Tis he that sow's sedition in the land,
Under the colour of being charitable,
When search is made for such in every inn,
Though I have seen them housed, the chamberlain
for gold will answer there is nobody:
He for all bankrupts is a common bail,
And when the execution should be served
Upon the sureties, they find nobody:
In private houses who so apt to lie,
As those that have been taught by nobody,
Servants forgetful of their master's friends,
Being asked how many were to speak with him
Whilst he was absent, they say nobody,
Nobody breaks more glasses in a house,
Than all his wealth hath power to satisfy:
If you will free this city then from shame,
Seize nobody, and let him bear the blame.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Lay hold upon him.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.l: What on nobody, give me my sword, my morglay,
My friends, you that do know how innocent I am,
Draw in my quarrel, succour nobody,
What nobody, but nobody remaining.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yes master, I nobody's man.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.l: Stand to me nobly then, and fear them not,
Thy master nobody, can take no wounds,
Nobody is no coward, nobody
Dares fight withal the world.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Upon them then.
sp.stage: A fight betwixt somebody and nobody, nobody escapes.
sp.l: What has he scaped us.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: He is gone my lord.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: It shall be thus, now you have seen his shape,
Let him be straight imprinted to the life:
His picture shall be set on every stall,
And proclamation made, that he that takes him,
Shall have a hundred pounds of somebody,
Country and city, I shall thus set free,
and have more room to work my villainy.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.l: What are they gone, than city now adieu,
Since I have taken such great injury,
For my good life within thy government:
No more will nobody be charitable,
No mote will nobody relieve the poor,
Honour your lord, and master somebody,
For somebody is he that wrongs you all.
I'll to the court the changing of the air,
May peradventure change my injuries,
And if I speed no better being there,
Yet say that nobody lived everywhere .

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: I was a King, but now I am slave,
How happy were I in this base estate,
If I had never tasted royalty:
But the remembrance that I was a King,
Unseasons the content of poverty,
I hear the hunter's music, here I'll lie,
To keep me out of sight till they pass by.

sp.speaker: Morgan.
sp.l: The stag is herded, come my lord
Shall we to horse and single him again.

sp.speaker: Malgo.
sp.l: Content, the King will chase, the day is spent
And we have killed no game, to horse, away.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: Herded, go single him, or couple straight,
He will not fall today, what fellows this.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.p: I am a man.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: A banished man I think,
My brother Archigallo, is't not so.

sp.speaker: Archi.
sp.l: 'Tis so, I am thy brother Elidure,
all that thou hast is mine, the crown is mine,
Thy royalty is mine; these hunting pleasures
Thou dost usurp: ambitious Elidure
I was a King.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.l: And I may be a wretch: poor Archigallo,
The sight of thee that wert my sovereign,
In this estate, draws rivers from mine eyes.
Will you be King again? if they agree
I'll redeliver all my royalty,
Save what a second brother and a subject
Keeps in an humble bosom, for I swear
The crown is yours that Elidure doth wear.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Then give it me; use not the common sleights,
To pity one, and keep away his right.
Seest thou these rags, do they become my person?
O Elidure, take pity on my state,
Let me not still live thus infortunate.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.l: Alas, if pity could procure your good,
Instead of water, I'd weep tears of blood
To express both love and pity: say dear brother
I should uncrown myself, the angry peers
Will never let me reach the imperial wreathe
To Archigallo's head. There's ancient Cornwell,
Stout Martianus, Morgan, and bold Malgo,
From whom you took the pleasant Southern I'll,
Will never kneel to you: what should I say,
Your tyranny was cause of your decay.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: What shall I die then? welcome be that fate
Rather than still live in this wretched state.

div.stage: Enter Cornwell, Martianus, Morgan and Malgo.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Yonder's the King; my sovereign you have lost
The fall of a brave stag, he's dead my liege.
What fellows this?

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.p: Knowest him not Cornwell?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: No my liege not I.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: I am thy King.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: 'Tis Archigallo man.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Thou art no King of mine, thou art a traitor,
Thy life is forfeit by thy stay in Britain.
Wert thou not banished?

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.l: Noble Cornwell speak
More gently, or my piteous heart will break,
Lord Martianus, Morgan, and the rest,
I am a weary of my government,
And willingly resign it to my brother.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Your brother was a tyrant, and my knee
Shall never bow to wrong and tyranny.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: Yet look upon his misery, his tears
Argue repentance; think not honoured lords
The fear of dangers waiting on my crown
Makes me so willing to resign the same,
For I am loved I know, but justice bids
I make a resignation, 'tis his right,
My calls but usurpation.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Elidure,
If you are weary of your government,
We'll set the crown upon a stranger's head
Rather than Archigallo. Hark ye lords,
Shall we make him our King we did depose,
So might our heads be chopped of, I'll lose mine
Ere my poor country shall endure such wrongs,
As that injurious tyrant plagues her with,

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Keep still your crown my liege, happy is Britain
Under the government of Elidure.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Let it be so,
Death is the happy period of all woe.
The wretch that's torn upon the torturing wrack,
Feels not more devilish torment then my heart.
When I but call to mind my tyranny,
I record heaven my lords, my brother's fight,
The pity that he takes of my distress,
Your love and true allegiance unto him,
Hath wrought in me a reconciled spirit,
I do confess my sin, and freely say,
I did deserve to be deposed.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.l: Alas good prince, my honourable lords,
Be not flint-hearted, pity Archigallo,
I know his penitential words proceed
From a remorseful spirit, I'll engage
My life upon his righteous government.
Good Cornwell, gentle Martianus, speak,
Shall Archigallo be your King again?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: By heaven I not desire it.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.l: See my lords,
He's not ambitious, as thou lovest me Cornwell,
As thou didst love our father, let his son
Be righted, give him back the government
You took from him.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: What should I say? faith I shall fall a weeping:
Therefore speak you.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: Lord Martianus speak.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: What say these lords that have been wronged by him.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.l: Morgan and Malgo, all I have in Britain
Shall be engaged to you, that Archigallo
Will never more oppress you, nor impose
Wrong on the meanest subject in the land.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.p: Then we'll embrace his government.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.p: Says Malgo so?

sp.speaker: Malg.
sp.p: I do my lord.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.p: What says Martianus?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Faith as my lord of Cornwell.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I say that I am sorry he was bad.
And now am glad he's changed; his wickedness
we punished, and his goodness there's great reason
Should be rewarded; therefore lords set on
To York then, to his coronation.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.l: Then happy Elidurus, happy day
That takes from me a kingdom's cares away.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: And happy Archigallo that have ranged
From sin, to sin, and now at last am changed.
My lords and friends, the wrongs that you have seen
In me, my future virtues shall redeem.
Come gentle brother, pity that should rest
In women most, is harboured in thy breast.

div.stage: Enter Queen, lady Elidure, and flatterer.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Come have you done your task, now do you see
What 'tis to be so proud of majesty,
We must take up your glove, and not be thought
Worthy the name of sister, thus you minx
I'll teach you ply your work, and thank me to,
This pains will be your own another day.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Insulting, overproud, ambitious woman ▪
Queen I disdain to call thee, thou dost wrong
Thy brother's wife, indeed thy Kings espoused,
And manger all thy tyranny I swear,
Rather than still live thus, I'll perish here.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: You are not wise, dejected as you are
To bandy braves against her majesty,
You must consider you are now her subject,
Your tongue is bounded by the awe of duty,
Fie, fie, I needs must chide you, since I see
You are so saucy with her sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Time was base spaniel thou didst fawn as much
On me, as now thou strivest to flatter her:
Oh God, that one born noble should be so base,
His generous blood to scandal all his race.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: My lord, if she continue these proud terms,
I give you liberty to punish her.
I'll not maintain my prisoner and my slave
To rail 'gainst any one that honours me.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Health to the Queen, and happiness to her
That must change states with you, and once more reign
Queen of this land.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Speak that again, o I will bless my fate,
If once more I supply my former state.

sp.speaker: Malgo.
sp.l: Long may your highness live, your banished lord
Is by his brother Elidurus seated
Once more in Britain's throne.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: O I could tear my hair, base Elidure
To wrong himself, and make a slave of me.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Now minion, I'll cry quittance with your pride,
And make you stoop at our imperial side ▪
But tell me Morgan by what accident
You met with my beloved Archigallo?

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Even in the woods where we did hunt the stag,
There did the tender hearted Elidure
Meet his distressed brother, and so wrought
By his importunate speech with all his peers,
That after much denial, yet at last
They yielded their allegiance to your lord,
Whom now we must acknowledge our dread King,
And you our princely Queen.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Thou screech-owl, raven, ugly throated slave ▪
There's for thy news.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Restrain her good my lord.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Fie madam fie, fore God you are too blame
In presence of my sovereign lady Queen
To be thus rude, it would become you better
To show more duty to her majesty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O monstrous, was not I thy Queen but now.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Yes, when your husband was my King you were.
But now the stream is turned, and the state's currant,
Runs all to Archigallo, blame not me,
Wisdom ne'er loved declined majesty.

div.stage: Enter Archigallo crowned, Elidure, Peridure, Vigenius, Cornwell, Martianus, and others.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Welcome from banishment my loving lord,
Your kingly presence wraps my soul to heaven.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: To heaven, and my kind brother Elidure,
Fair Queen we owe chief thanks for this our greatness,
Next them, these honourable lords.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Great Queen,
Once more the tribute of our bent knees
We pay to you, and humbly kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: So doth Martianus.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Vige.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Our brothers, by how much that name exceeds
The name of lord, so much the more this duty
Deserves requital, thanks both, and thanks to all.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.p: Set on there.

div.stage: Exeunt all but lady and sycophant

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Madam, you are not wise to grieve at that
Heaven hath decreed, and the state yielded to,
No doubt her majesty will use you well.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Well sayest thou: no I look that she should treble
All the disgraces I have laid on her.
I shall turn laundress now, and learn to starch,
And set and poke, and pocket up such baseness
As never Princess did: did you observe
What looks I cast at Elidure my husband?

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Your looks declared the passion of your heart,
They were all fire.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Would they had burned his eyes out
That hath eclipsed our state and majesty.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Bring hither the proud wife of Elidure,

sp.speaker: Sicop.
sp.p: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Our shoe string is untied, stoop minion, stoop.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I'll rather stoop to death thou moon-like Queen,
New changed, and yet so proud: there's those are made
For flexure, let them stoop, thus much I'll do,
You are my Queen, 'tis but a debt I owe.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Bring me the work there, I will task you to,
That by the hour spin it, I charge you do.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: A distaff and a spindle, so indeed
I told you this, Diana be my speed.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Yet for his princely worth that made you Queen
Respect her as the wife of Elidure.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.p: Where's the Queen?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: What news with Cornwell, why so sad my lord?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Your husband on the sudden is fallen sick.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: How; sick.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Now if it be thy will, sweet blessed heaven
Take him to mercy.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: Do not hear her prayers heaven I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Madam, his highness.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Is he alive, or dead.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Dead madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.p: O my heart.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Look to the Queen, let us not lose her to,
She breathes, stand of, where be those women there,
Good Queen that shall be, lends a helping hand,
help to unlace her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll see her burst first.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Now as you love me let no helping hand
Preserve life in me, I had rather die
Then lose the title of my sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Take back your distaff yet, we'll stay our rage,
We will forbear our spleen for charity
And love unto the dead, till you have hearsed
Your husband's bones, conduct her lords away,
Our pride though eager, yet for food shall stay.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Will't please your high imperial majesty
Command my service, I am humbly yours.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: We do command what we well know you'll do,
Follow the stronger part, and cleave thereto.

div.stage: Enter Elidure crowned, all the lords and ladies' attendants.

sp.speaker: Elidu.
sp.l: Once more our royal temples are ingirt
With Britain's golden wreath, all seeing heaven
Witness I not desire this sovereignty,
But since this kingdoms good, and your decrees,
Have laid this heaven load of common care
On Elidure, we shall discharge the same
To your content, I hope, and this land's fame:
Our brother once interred, we will not stay,
But then to Troynovant we'll speed, away.

sp.speaker: 1 porter
sp.l: Come fellow porter, now the court is here
Our gains will fly upon us like a tide,
Let us make use of time, and whilst there's plenty
Stirring in court, still labour to increase
The wealth which by our office we have got.

sp.speaker: 2 porter.
sp.l: Out of our large allowance we must save
Of thousands that pass by us, and our office,
we will give entertainment to nobody.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: My name is nobody,

sp.speaker: 1. Porter
sp.l: You are welcome sir, ere you peruse the court,
Taste the King's beer, here at the porter's lodge,
A dish of beer for master nobody.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Porter
sp.l: Here master nobody, withal my heart,
A full carouse, and welcome to our office.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.l: I thank you sir, and were your beer tems water,
Yet nobody would pledge you, to you sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Porter
sp.l: You are a stranger here, how in the city,
Have you been long in town.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.l: Ay sir, too long, unless my entertain
Had been more pleasing, for my life is sought,
I am a harmless well disposed plain man,
That injure none, yet whatsoe'er is done
Amiss in London, is imposed on me,
Be it lying, secret theft, or any thing
They call abuse, 'tis done by nobody,
I am pursued by all, and now am come,
To see what safety is within the court
For a plain fellow.

sp.speaker: 2. Por.
sp.l: You are welcome hither sir.
Methinks you do look wild, as if you wanted sufficient sleep.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.l: O do not blame me sir,
Being pursued I fled, coming though Paul's,
There nobody kneeled down to say his prayers,
And was devout I wis, coming through Fleetstreet,
There at a tavern door two swaggerers
Were fighting, being attached, 'twas asked who gave
The first occasion, 'twas answered nobody,
The guilt was laid on me, which made me fly
To the Thames' side, desired a waterman,
to row me thence away to Charing-cross,
He asked me for his fare, I answered him
I had no money, what's your name quoth he,
I told him nobody, than he bade me welcome,
Said he would carry nobody for nothing.
From thence I went
To see the law courts held at Westminster,
There meeting with a friend, I straight was asked
If I had any suit, I answered, yes,
Marry I wanted money, sir quoth he,
For you, because your name is nobody
I will solicit law, and nobody
Assure yourself, shall thrive by suits in law,
I thanked him, and so came to see the court,
Where I am very much beholding to your kindness.

sp.speaker: 1. Porter
sp.l: And master nobody you are very welcome,
Good fellow lead him to the hall,
Will you walk near the court.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Fie what a toil it is to find out nobody,
I have dogged him very close, yet he is got into the court before me.
Sir you have sworn to fight with nobody,
Do you stay here, and watch at the court gate,
And when you meet him challenge him the field,
Whilst I set lime-twigs for him in all offices,
If either you or I, but prosper right,
He needs must fall by policy or slight.

sp.speaker: Brag:
sp.l: I would this roundman nobody would come,
I that profess much valour yet have none,
Cannot but be too hard for nobody,
For what can be in nobody, unless
He be so called because he is all spirit,
Or say he be all spirit, wanting limbs,
how can this spirit hurt me, sure he dies,
And by his death, my fame shall mount the skies.

sp.speaker: Nobody.
sp.l: By thy leave my sweet friend,
There's for thy farewell.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Stay.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: That's but one word, let two go to the bargain if it please you, why should I stay.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: I challenge thee.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: I may choose whether I'll answer your challenge by your leave.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I'll have thee pictured as thy picture, unless thou answer me

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: For what sir, pray why would you have me printed.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: For cowardice.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: Methinks your picture would do better for the picture of cowardice than mine sir, but pray what's your will with me.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Thou hast abused one somebody,

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: So have my betters abused somebody in their time

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: I'll fight with thee for that.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Alas sir I am nobody at fighting, yet thus much let me tell you, nobody cannot run away, I cannot budge.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Prepare thee then, for I will spit thy body upon this weapon.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: Nay by faith that you cannot, for I have nobody .

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Thy bowels then.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: They are the fairer mark a great deal, come on sir, come on

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Have at thy belly.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: You must either hit that or nothing.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: I'll kill and quarter thee.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.l: You'll hardly find my joints I think to quarter me,
I am so well fed, come on sir.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: Now thou art at my mercy.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: What are you the better to have nobody at your mercy

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: I'll kill thee now.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.l: I think you'll sooner kill me then anybody ,
But let me rise again.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: No I will let nobody rise.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: Why then let me sir, I am nobody,

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: How now, oh fates, oh heavens, is not that my m.
What shall I do, be valiant ▪ and rescue my sweet master,
Avant thou pagan, Pug, whate'er thou be,
Behold I come to set thy prisoner free.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: Fortune that giddy goddess hath turned her wheel,
I shall be matched, thus will I gore you both. Hold captains,
Not Hercules himself would fight with two, I yield.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.l: 'Twas your best course, down vassal down, and kiss
My pump.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: 'Tis base, oh base.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Zounds, I'll nail thy lips to limbo unless thou kiss.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: Thanks honest servant.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Zounds if I say I'll do't, I'll do't indeed.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.l: For this I'll carry thee into the court,
Where thou shalt see thy master nobody
Hath friends will bid him welcome, so farewell,

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Farewell master braggart, farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Brag.
sp.l: I'll follow, I shall meet with somebody,
That will revenge, I'll plot and ere't be long
I'll be revenged on nobody for this wrong.

div.stage: Enter Vigenius Peridure and the Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Your hopes are great fair brothers, and your names, shall if in this you be advised by us,
Be ranked in scroll of all the British Kings,
O take upon you this so weighty charge,
Too great to be discharged by Elidure.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Dear sister Q. how are we bound to you,
In nearer bonds than a fraternal league,
for this your royal practice to raise us,
Unto the height of honour and estate,
Let me no longer breathe a prince on earth,
Or think me worthy of your regal blood,
If we embrace not this high motion.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Embrace it brother, we are all on speed,
My princely thought inflamed with ardency
Of this imperial state, and sceptered rule,
My kingly brows, itch for a stately crown,
This hand to bear a round monarchal globe,
This the bright sword of justice, and stern awe,
Dear sister you have made me all on fire,
My kingly thoughts, beyond their bounds aspire.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: How shall we quit your love, when we ascend
The state of Elydure.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: All that I crave,
Is but to make the imperious Queen my slave,
That she that above justice now commands,
May taste new thraldom at our royal hands.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: The Queen is yours, the King shall be deposed,
And she disgraded from all sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: That I might live to see that happy hour,
To have that stern commandress in my power.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: She's doomed already, and at your dispose,
And we prepared for speedy execution,
Of any plot that may avail our pomp,
Or throne us in the state of Brittany.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Here comes the lords of this pretended league,
How goes our hope, speak valiant English peers,
Are we in way of sovereignty, or still stand we
Subjects unto the awe of Elidure.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Long live the valiant brothers of the King,
With mutual love to wear the British crown,
two thousand soldiers have I brought from Wales,
To wait upon the princely Peridure.

sp.speaker: Malg.
sp.l: As many of my bold confederates
Have I drawn from the South to swear allegiance,
To young Vigenius.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Do but call me King,
The charming spheres so sweetly cannot sing.

sp.speaker: Malg,
sp.p: To King Vigenius.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: O but where's our crown,
That make knees humble, when their sovereigns frown.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: King Elidure's shall his state resign.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Say Morgan so, and Britain's rule is mine.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: King Peridure shall reign.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: And sit in state.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And thousand subjects on his glory wait.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Then they that lifts us to the imperial seat,
Our powers and will shall study to make great.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: And thou that raisest us, as our best friend,
Shall as we mount the like degrees ascend.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: When will you give the attempt.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Now royal sister.
Before the King have notice of our plot,
Before the lords that love his government,
Prepare their opposition.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Well determined,
And like a King in esse, now this night,
Let's make a hostile uproar in the court,
Surprise the King, make seizure of the crown,
Lay hands upon the counsel, lest they scape
To levy forces, those lords
That serve the King, and with austere reproofs,
Punish the hateful vices of the land,
Must not awe us, they shall not reign, we will,
Those that applaud us, raise, despise us, kill,

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: I see a kind of state appear already
In thy majestic brow, call in the soldiers,
man the court gates, barricade all the streets,
Defend the ways, the lands and passages,
And girt the palace with a treble wall
Of armed soldiers, and in dead of night,
When all the peers lie drowned in golden sleep,
Sound out a sudden and a shrill alarum,
To maze them in the midst of horrid dreams.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: The King and crown is ours.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The Queen I claim.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: It shall go hard, but I the shrew will tame,
Trumpets and drums, your dreadful clamours sound.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Proclaim me captive, or a King new crowned,

div.stage: Alarum, they watch the doors, enter at one door Cornwell ▪

sp.speaker: Corn
sp.p: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Thou art mine whate'er thou be.

sp.speaker: Corn
sp.p: Prince Peridure.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: I Cornwell and thy King.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: He discords taught, that taught thee so to sing.

div.stage: Alarum enter at another door Martianus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Who stops this passage.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Martianus we.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Vigenius.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Unto whom thou owest thy knee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My knee to none ▪ but Elidure shall bend.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Our reign beginning hath when his lines end.

div.stage: Alarum, enter at another door Elydure, stopped by the Queen.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What traitorous hand dares interdict our way?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Why that dare ours, 'tis we command thee stale.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Are we not Queen?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Is't you, then happily met,
I have owed you long, and now I'll pay that debt.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Vild traitress, darest, thou lay a violent hand on us thy Queen?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: We dare command thee stand,
Thou wast a Queen, but now thou art a slave.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Before such bondage, grant me heaven a grave.

sp.speaker: Elidure.
sp.l: What seek ye lords? What mean these loud
Alarms, in the still silence of this hunnied night?

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: King we seek thee.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: And more we seek thy crown.

sp.speaker: Elidure.
sp.l: Why princely brothers is it not our own,
That 'tis ours we plead the law of Kings,
The gift of heaven, and the antiquity on earth,
Election from them both.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: We plead our powers and strength, we two must reign.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: We were born to rule, and homage we disdain.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Do not resign, good King.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: How saucy lord?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I'll keep still thy crown.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: I say that word shall cost old Cornwall's life.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Tush this for care.
Tyrant's good subjects kills and traitors spare.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Wilt thou submit thy crown?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Dread sovereign, no.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: He hates his own life that adviseth so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I hate all traitors, and had rather die,
Then see such wrong done to his sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Give up thy state to these two princely youths, and thy resignment shall preserve thy life.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Wilt thou so much wrong both thyself and wife?
Hast lived a King, and canst thou die a slave,
A royal seat, doth ask a royal grave,
though thousand swords thy present safety ring,
Thou that hast been a monarch, die a King.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Whether he live or die, thou sure shalt be no longer Queen, but vassal unto me, I'll make ye now my drudge.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How minion, thine?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Thou'rt no more Queen, thy husband must resign.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Resign, to whom?

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: I am one.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: And I another.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Canst be so base to see a younger brother,
Nay two young boys placed in thy throne of state,
And thou their sudden in their trains to wait,
I'll die before I endure it.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: So shall all,
That do not prostrate to our homage fall.
Shall they not brother King?

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: They shall by heaven.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come kill me first.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Nay make the number even,
And kill me to, for I am pleased to die,
Rather than this endure.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The third am I.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Nay strike her first.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Rage give my fury way.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Strike valiant brother King.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: Yet he are me, stay.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Be brief for God's sake then,

sp.speaker: Elidure.
sp.l: O heaven, that men so much should covet care,
Sceptres are golden baits, the outsides fair:
But he that swallows this sweet sugared pill,
'Twill make him sick with troubles that grow still:
Alas you seek to ease me being wearied
And lay my burden on your able loins,
My unambitious thoughts have been long tired,
with this great charge, and now they rest desired,
And see the kind youths coveting my peace,
Bring me of all these turmoils free release.
Here take my crown.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Wilt thou be made a stale,
Shall this proud woman, and these boys prevail?
Shall I for them be made a public scorn,
O hadst thou buried been, as soon as born,
How happy had I been.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: Patience sweet wife,
Thinkst thou I praise my crown above thy life,
No take it lords, it hath my trouble been,
And for this crown, o give me back my Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Nay she's bestowed on me.

sp.speaker: Elydure.
sp.l: Then what you please,
Here take my trouble, and resign your ease.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: My lords receive the crown of Elydure,
Fair hopeful blossoms of our future peace,
Happy am I, that I but live to see,
The land ruled by your double sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Now let the King descend to be disposed of
At our high pleasure, come give me the crown.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Why you the crown, good brother more than we.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: We'll prove it how it fits our kingly temples,
And how our brow becomes a wreath so fair.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Shall I see you crowned, and myself stand bare,
Rather this wreath majestic let me try,
And sit enthroned, in pompious majesty.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: And I attend, whilst you ascend the throne,
Where had we right, we should sit crowned alone.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Alone, dar'st thou usurp upon my right.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: I durst do much, had I but power and might,
But wanting that, come let us reign together,
Both Kings, and yet the rich crown worn by neither.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Content, the King doth on our sentence wait,
to doom him, come let's take our double state,
What shall he live, or die?

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: I know not how I should deserve to die.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes to let two such usurpers live.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: Nay madam, now I needs must tell your grace,
You wrong these Kings, forget both time and place,
It is not as it was, now you must bow,
Unto this double state I'll show you how.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Base flattering groom slavish parasite,

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Shall I pronounce his sentence.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Brother do.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Thy life we grant thee and that woman's to,
But live divided you within the tower,
You prisoner to that Princess.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: In her power,
O double slavery.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Convey both hence.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: My dooms severer than my small offence.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Come minion, will you go.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: To death, to hell,
Rather than in thy base subjection dwell.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Cornwell and Martianus you both see,
We are possessed of this imperial seat,
And you that were sworn liegemen to the crown,
Should now submit to us that owe the same,
We know without your grave directions,
We cannot with experience guide the land,
Therefore we'll study to deserve your loves.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: 'Twas not ambition, or the love of state,
That drew us to this business, but the fear,
Of Elidurus' weakness whom in zeal,
To the whole land we have deposed this day,
Speak, shall we have your loves?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: My lords, and Kings,
'Tis bootless to contend 'gainst heaven and you,
since without our consent the Kings deposed,
And we unable to support his fall,
Rather than the whole land should shrink,
You shall have my assistance in the state.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Cornwell and I will bear the self same state.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: We now are Kings indeed and Britain sway,
When Cornwell and his brother Vive say

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Receive our grace, keep still your offices,
