Embrace these peers that raised us to the throne,
Britain rejoice, and crown this happy year,
Two sons at once thine in thy royal sphere.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: And that's prodigious, I but wait the time
To see their sudden fall that swiftly climb.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My lord much honour might you win your land
To give release unto your sister Queen,
Being a lady in the land beloved.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: You have advised us well, it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Should you set free the Princess might not she
Make uproars in the land, and raise the commons.
In the releasement of the captive King.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Well counselled Cornwell, she shall live in bondage.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Renown yourself by being kind to her.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Secure your state by her imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: We'll have the Queen set free.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: We'll have her guarded,
With stricter keeping and severer charge.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will you be braved by one that's but your equal,
Having no more than party government.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Or you be scorned by one to you inferior,
In general estimation of the land.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Set free the Princess, say the King commands.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Keep her in thraldom still, and captive bands.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: We'll not be countermanded.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Sir nor we.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Before I'll be half a King and controlled
in any regality, I'll hazard all,
I'll be complete or none.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Before I'll stand,
Thus for a cipher with my half command,
I'll venture all my fortunes, how now pride,
Perched on my upperhand.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: By heaven well spied.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: 'Tis ours by right, and right we will enjoy.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Claimest thou pre-eminence, come down proud boy

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Then let's try masteries, and one conquer all,
We climbed at once, and we at once will fall.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: They that love Peridure divide themselves upon their part.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: That am I.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: They that love us on this side.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Then to the field, to set our sister free.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: By all my hopes with her I'll captive thee.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Trumpets and drums, triumphant music sing.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: This day a captive, or a complete King.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Sir you have sworn to manage these affairs,
Even with your best of judgement.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.l: I have provided, you will let me share,
Of the grand-benefit you get by dice,
Deceitful cards, and other cozening games
You bring into the court.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: O rare, now shall I find out crab, some notable knavery

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: You shall have equal share with somebody,
Provided, you will help to apprehend that nobody,
On whom the guilt shall lie,
Of all those cheting tricks I have devised.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: O the fates, treason against my m. person, but I believe
Somb. will pay fort, I'll tickle your long waist for this i'faith,

sp.speaker: Sico.
sp.p: Give me some bales of dice. What are these?

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Those are called high fulloms.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I'll fullom you for this.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Those low fulloms ▪

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: They may chance bring you as high as the gallows.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Those demi-bars.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Great reason you should come to the bar before the gallows.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Those bar sizeaces.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A couple of asses indeed.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Those bristle dice.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: 'Tis like they bristle, for I am sure they'll breed anger

sp.speaker: Sicop.
sp.l: Now sir, as you have compassed all the dice,
So I for cards. These for the game at maw,
All saving one, are cut next under that,
Lay me the ace of hearts, then cut the cards,
Oh your fellow must needs have it in his first trick.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I'll teach you a trick for this i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sicop.
sp.l: These for premero cut upon the sides,
As the other on the ends.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Mark the end of all this.

sp.speaker: Sicop.
sp.l: These are for post and pair, these for saunt,
These for new cut.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: They'll make you cut a feather one day,

sp.speaker: Sycophant
sp.l: Well, these dispersed, and nobody
Attached for all these crimes, shall be hanged.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I or else you shall hang for him,

sp.speaker: Sycophant
sp.p: Come, shall's about our business.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Content, let's straight about it.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p:
O my heart, that it was my fortune to hear all this,
but beware a lucky man whilst you live, alas if I had not rescued my master, the swaggering fellow would have made nobody of him. Again if I had not overheard this treason to his person, these coney-catching knaves, would have made less than nobody of him. For indeed they would have hanged him, but here's my master, oh sweet master how cheer you?

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: O excellent, admirable, and beyond comparison, I think my shape enchants them.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I think not so, for if I were a lady, I should never abide you: but master, I can tell you rare news you must be apprehended, for a cheater, a cozener, a libeller, and I know not what.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.p: Not I, I am an innocent, no cheater, no cozener, but a simple honest man, hunted from place to place by somebody.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: 'Tis true sir, it is one some. that would attach you, therefore
Look to yourself, but Mai. if you be taken never fear,
I heard all their knavery, and I can clear you I warrant.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: O have I found you, this is he my friends,
We have long sought, you know when 'twas enquired,
Who brought the false dice, and the cheating cards
Into the court, 'twas answered nobody.

sp.speaker: Clown No.
sp.p: (quoth than) I am afraid you'll prove the knave some.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Lay hold upon him, bear him to the prison.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: To prison, say you well, if I be guilty this fellow is my partner take him to.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Are you confederate in this treason sirrah?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: If I be not sir somebody is, but if I be guilty I must bear
If off with head and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: To prison with them, now the bird is caught,
for whom so long, through Britain have I sought.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I believe I have a bird in a box, shall catched you for all this.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Away with them I say.

div.stage: Enter severally Peridure, Vigenius, Cornewell, Martianus, Morgan, Malgo, with drum and colours.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: In arms well met, ambitious Peridure,

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Vigenius thou salutes me with a title,
Most proper to thyself,

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Art thou not proud.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Only to meet thee on this bed of death,
Wherein the title to the English crown,
Shall perish with thyself.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Fair is the end
Of such as die in honourable war,
O far more fair, then on a bed of down.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: War is the soldier's harvest it cuts down.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: The lives of such as hinder our renown.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Such as are apt for tumult.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Such as you,
That to our lawful sovereign are untrue.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Blushes not Peridure to brave us so.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: Blushes Vigenius at thy overthrow,
Who wast that told me he would submit.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: 'Twas I my lord.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Peace fool thou dost forget,
'Tis not an hour since, to our princely ear,
Thou saidst thou did desire us to forbear.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: True my good lord.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: True that I sought to stay.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: That I would basely my rich hopes betray.

sp.speaker: Sico.
sp.p: I did it of mine own head to make you friends.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Still playing of the sycophant.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: What still.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: A gloze I see to insinuate our good will.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: That whosoever conquered, he might gain.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: The favour of us both, that was his train.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: But henceforth we cashier thee from the filled.

sp.speaker: Perid
sp.l: Never hereafter bear a soldier's shield,
A soldier's sword, nor any other grace,
But what is like thine own, a double face.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.p: Now I beseech Jove hear my prayer, let them be both slain in the battle.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.l: If there be any other of his heart,
We give them free licence to depart.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Cornwell hates flattery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So does Martianus.

sp.speaker: Malg.
sp.p: Malgo is resolute for all affairs.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.p: And so is Morgan, for he scorns delays.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.l: Then where the field consists of such a spirit,
He that subdues conquers the crown by merit.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: That's I.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Rivers in blood declare it.

sp.speaker: Vig.
sp.p: Grass turn to crimson if Vigenius spare it.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: Air be made purple with our reaking gore.

sp.speaker: Vige.
sp.p: Follow my friends.

sp.speaker: Perid.
sp.p: Conquer or ne'er give o'er.

div.stage: Alarum, excursious, Periduras, and Vigenius fight, and both slain.
Enter cornwell, Martianus, Morgan, and Malgo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This way I saw Vigenius on the spur.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I Periduras, this way.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.p: A strange fight, my lord is breathless.

sp.speaker: Malg.
sp.p: My dear lord is dead.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: True brothers in ambition, and in death.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Yet we are enemies, why fight we not
With one another, for our general's loss.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To much blood already hath been spent,
Now therefore since the difference in themselves,
Is reconciled in either's overthrow,
Let us be as we were before this jar,
And joining hands like honourable friends,
Inter their bodies as becomes their state,
And which is rare once more to Elidure,
Who now in prison leads a wearied life,
With true submission offer England's crown.
Of all the charges of tumultuous fate,
This is most strange three times to flow in state.

sp.speaker: Sico.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You are welcome, what new flatteries,
Are a coining in the mint of that smooth face?

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: Where is the lady Elidor I pray.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Amongst my other waiting maids at work.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.l: 'Tis well, yet madam with your gracious leave
I wish it better.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What in love with her,
Canst thou affect such a dejected wretch,
Than I perceive thy flattery is folly,
Or thou'lt prove honest, loving one so poor.

sp.speaker: Sico.
sp.l: I know not madam what your highness gathers
Out of my troubled words, I love you well,
And though the time should alter, as I am sure,
It is impossible, yet I would follow
All your misfortunes with a patient heart.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: I have seen too much of thee to credit thee.

sp.speaker: Sico.
sp.l: Now in your height of glory use your servant,
now madam, whilst the noble Peridure
That loves you dearer than the British crown,
Whilst he's conqueror, use me to destroy
Your greatest enemy, and I will do it.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Thou wilt not.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.l: Be it Elidure the King,
The prisoner I should say, I'd murder him,
To show how much I love your majesty.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Thou wouldst not poison for me his base Queen,
Whom I so often have triumphed o'er,
That torment now is her beatitude,
And tedious unto me.

sp.speaker: Sycophant
sp.p: No more, she's dead.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: See where she comes, dispatch her presently,
For though the princely Peridure be King,
His brother's death in time will make him odious
Unto his subjects, and they may restore
Mild Elidure again, and then I die,

sp.speaker: Sycophant
sp.p: Withdraw, she's dead, as surely as you live.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What shall I never from this servitude
Receive releasant evermore be plagued,
With this insulting Queen? Is there no change,
No other alteration in the state
I know there is not, I am born to be
A slave, to one baser than slavery

sp.speaker: Sioo.
sp.p: I will release you by a speedy death.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: By death, alas, what tongue pronounced that word?
What my lord Weathercock? nay then I see,
Death in thy mouth is but base flattery.

sp.speaker: Sycophant
sp.p: By heaven I am sent to kill you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: By whose means.

sp.speaker: Sycophant
sp.p: By one that will avouch it when 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not the proud Queen.

sp.speaker: Sycophant
sp.l: Yes, but I am determined
In full amends for all my flattery,
To save your life, and kill her instantly.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: O if a devil would undertake that deed,
I carded not though she heard me, I would say,
He were a star more glorious than the day.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.p: And would you for that good deed pardon me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And quite all former injury.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.l: But let me tell your highness by the way,
The Queen is not so hasty of your death.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, for she had rather have my life prolonged.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.l: I do assure your highness on mine honour,
When I did say she sent me to destroy you,
I slandered her great mercy towards you,
For she had given me order to release you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O monstrous lie.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.l: Believe it, for 'tis true:
And this moreover, she somuch repents
Her former pride and hardness towards you,
That she could wish it never had been done.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Then I repent me of my wrongs towards her,
And in the stead of a reward proposed
To him that should destroy her, I do wish,
Death be his death, that undertakes the deed.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.l: But will you not forget these princely words,
If any alteration should ensue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not I, I in my oaths am true.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.p: Except once more the lords crown Elydure.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Though that should chance, I'll hold my promise sure.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.p: And you too madam.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So thou murder'st her.

sp.speaker: Sycophant
sp.l: Know that lord Periduras and his
Brother, are in the battle slain, and by the nobles,
Her husband Elidure raised to the state,
Setting aside all jesting, Queen believe it.
And truce with her, lest she triumph again.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: For god's sake make us friends.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.p: Good lord how strange this reconciled foes behold each other.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sister.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Kind sister.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.p: Then make me your brother, say are you friends.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We are.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.l: Then chance what can,
In this I have proved myself an honest man.

sp.speaker: Malgo.
sp.l: The King your husband, madam new released,
Desires your presence at his coronation.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Elydure a third time to be crowned.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: True madam, and expects your company.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And you knew this before.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.p: No on mine honour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Neither you sister.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If you did my oath is past, and what I have lately sworn I'll hold inviolate, here all strife ends, thy wit has made two proud shrews perfect friends.

div.stage: Enter in state, Elidure, Cornwell, Martianus, Morgan, and all the lords.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: A third time live our gracious sovereign
Monarch of England, crowned by these hands.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: A third time lords, I do return your love,
And wish it with my soul, so heaven were pleased,
My ambitious brothers had not died for this,
But we have given them honourable graves.
And mourned their most untimely funeral,
My loved Queen, come seat thee by my side,
Partner in all my sorrows and my joys,
And you her reconciled sister sit,
By her in second place of majesty,
It joys me that you have outworn your pride.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Methinks my gracious husband and my King,
I never took more pleasure in my glass,
Than I receive in her society.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Nor I in all my state as in her love.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: My lord of Cornwell, who's that whispers to you?
Or what's the news?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: My liege, he tells me here's a great contention
Betwixt two noted persons of the land
Much spoke of by all states, one somebody
Hath brought before your highness and this presence,
An infamous and strange opinioned fellow,
Called nobody, they would entreat your highness,
To hear their matters scanned.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: We'll sit in person on their controversies,
Admit them Cornwell.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Is that strange monster took, somuch renowned,
In city, court, and country, for lewd pranks.
'Tis well, we'll hear how he can purge himself.

div.stage: Enter somebody, bringing in nobody and his man, with bills and staves.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Now sirrah we have brought you before the King,
Where's your heart now?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.p: My hearts in my hose, but my face was never ashamed to show itself, yet before King or keyser.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: And where's your heart sirrah?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: My hearts lower than my hoof, for mine it at my heel, but wheresoever it is, it is a true heart, and so is not somb.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Health to your majesty, and to the Queen,
With a heart lower than this humble earth
Whereon I kneel. I beg against this fellow,
Justice my liege.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: Against whom.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Against nobody.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: My liege, his words well suit unto his thoughts,
He wishes no man justice, being composed
Of all deceit, of subtlety and slight,
For mine own part, if in this royal presence,
And before all these true judicial lords,
I cannot with sincereness clear myself,
Of all suggestions falsely coined against me,
Let me be hanged up sunning in the air,
And made a scarecrow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let's hear his accusations,
And then how well thou canst acquit thyself.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: First, when this monster made his residence
Within the country, and dispersed his shape
Through every shire and country of the land,
Where plenty had before a quiet seat,
And the poor commons of the land were full,
With rich abundance and satiety,
At his arrive, great dearths and scarcity,
By engrossing come, and racking poor men's rends.
This makes so many poor and honest farmers,
To sell their leases, and to beg their bread,
This makes so many beggars in the land.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I but what proof or lawful evidence
Can you bring forth, that this was done by him.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: My lord I traced him, and so found him out,
But should your lordship not believe my proof,
Examine all the rich and wealthy chuffs,
whose full crammed garners to the roofs are filled,
In every dearth who makes this scarcity,
And every man will clearly quit himself,
Then consequently, it must be nobody.
Base copper money is stamped, the mint disgraced,
Make search who doth this, every man clears one,
So consequently it must be nobody.
Besides, whereas the nobles of the land,
And gentlemen built goodly manner houses,
Fit to receive a King, and all his train,
And there kept royal hospitality,
Since this intestine monster nobody,
Dwells in these goodly houses keeps no train,
A hundred chimneys, and not one cast smoke,
And now the cause of these, mock-beggar Hal,
Is this they, are dwelled in by nobody,
For this out of the country he was chaste.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: My royal liege why am I thus disgraced,
I'll prove that slanderous wretch hath this all done.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: 'Tis good you can acquit you, such abuses,
Grow in the country, and unknown to us:
Nay then no marvel that so many poor,
Starve in the streets and beg from door, to door.
Then sirrah purge you from this country blame,
Or we will make thee the world's public shame.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Now nobody, what can you say to this.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My m. hath good cards, on his side I'll warrant him.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: My lord, you know that slanders are no proofs,
Nor words without their present evidence,
If things were done, they must be done by somebody,
Else could they have no being. Is corn hoarded,
Somebody hoards it, else it would be dealt,
In mutual plenty throughout all the land,
Are their rends raised, if nobody should do it,
Then should it be undone. Is
base money stamped, and the King's letters forged,
Somebody needs must do it, therefore not I,
And where he says, great houses long since built,
Lie destitute, and waste because inhabited,
By nobody my liege, I answer thus,
If somebody dwelled therein, I would give place.
Or would he but allow those chimney's fire,
They would cast clouds to heaven, the kitchen-food
It would relieve the poor, the cellar's beer,
It would make strangers drink, but he commits
These outrages then lays the blame on me,
And for my good deed, I am made a scorn.
I only give the tired a refuge seat,
The unclothed garments, and the starved meat.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: How say you by this master somebody. I believe
You will be found out by and by.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: If this be true my liege, as true it is,
Somebody will be found an arrant cheater,
Unless he better can acquit himself.

sp.speaker: Sich.
sp.p: Touch him with the city, since you have taken the foil in the country.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sirrah, what can you say to this?

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: What should I say my lord, see hear complaints,
Made in the city against nobody,
As well as in the country. See their bills,
Here's one complains his wife hath been abroad,
And asking where she revels night, by night,
She answers she hath been with nobody.
Here's queans maintained in every suburb street,
Ask who maintains them, and 'tis nobody.
Watches are, beaten, and constables are scoffed,
In dead of night men are made drunk in taverns,
Girls lose their maiden heads at thirteen years,
Pockets picked, and purses cut in throngs.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Enough, enough, doth nobody all this?
Though he hath cleared himself from country crimes,
He cannot scape the city.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: Yes dread Queen,
I must confess these things are daily done,
For which I here accuse this somebody,
That everywhere with slanders dogs my steps,
And cunningly assumes my borrowed shape,
Women lie out, if they be taken and found
With somebody, than nobody goes clear,
Else the blames mine, he doth these faults unknown,
Then slanders my chaste innocence for proof.
Somebody doth maintain a common strumpet
Ith' garden-allys, and undid himself.
Somebody swaggered with the watch last night,
Was carried to the counter.
Somebody once picked a pocket in this playhouse yard,
Was hoisted on the stage, and shamed about it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Ha, ha, hath my master met with you.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: Alas my liege, your honest nobody
Builds churches in these days, and hospitals,
Relieves the several prisons in the city,
Redeems the needy debtor from the hole,
And when this somebody brings infant children,
And leaves them in the night at stranger's doors,
Nobody fathers them, provides them nurses,
What should I say, your highness' love I crave,
That am all just.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Then somebody's a knave.

sp.speaker: Sicophant
sp.p: If neither city nor country will prevail to him, with the court ma. somebody, and there you will match him.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Then touching his abuses in the court.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I marry nobody what say you to this,
See, here are dangerous libils 'gainst the state,
And no name to them, therefore nobody's.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Besides strange rumours and false buzzing tales,
of mutinous leesings raised by nobody.

sp.speaker: Malg.
sp.p: False dice and cheating brought even to the presence, and who dares be so impudently knavish,
Unless some fellow of your name and garb.

sp.speaker: Morg.
sp.l: Cards of advantage with such cheating tricks,
Brought even amongst the noblest of the land,
And when these cozening shifts are once discovered,
There is no cheater found save nobody.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: How canst thou answer these.

sp.speaker: Nobo.
sp.l: Even as the rest,
Are libels cast, if nobody did make them,
And nobody's name to them, they are no libels,
For he that sets his name to any slander,
Makes it by that no libel, this approves
He forged those slanderous writs to scandal me.
And for false cards, and dice, let my great slops
And his big bellied doublet both be searched,
And see which harbours most hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Let them both be searched.

sp.speaker: Sycophant
sp.p: I'll take my leave of the presence.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Nay m. sycophant we'll have the inside of your pockets translated to, we'll see what stuffing they have, I'll take a little pains with you.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.p: What have you there in nobody's pockets.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Here are my liege bonds forfeit by poor men,
Which he released out of the usurer's hands,
And cancelled. Leases likewise forfeited,
By him repurchased. These petitions,
Of many poor men to prefer their suits.
Unto your highness.

sp.speaker: Elid.
sp.l: Thou art just we know,
All great men's pockets should be lined so.

sp.speaker: Quern.
sp.p: What bombast bears his gorge.

sp.speaker: M●r.
sp.l: False cards, false dice;
The King's hand counterfeit,
bonds put in suit to gain the forfeitures,
Forged deeds to cheat men of their ancient land,
And thousand such like trash.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Nay look you here, hears one that for his bones is prettily stuffed. Here's fulloms and gourds: here's tall-men and low-men here trey duce ace, passage comes a pace.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.p: Mercy great King.

sp.speaker: Sicoph.
sp.p: Mercy my sovereign.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: My liege you cannot to be severe in punishing,
Those monstrous crimes, the only stain and blemish
To the weal-public.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Villains hear your doom,
Thou that hast been the oppression of the poor,
Shalt be more poor than penury it self,
All that thou hast is forfeit to the law,
For thy extortion I will have thee branded,
Upon the forehead with the letter F.
For cheating whipped, for forging lose thine ears,
Last for a basing of thy sovereign's coin,
And traitorous impress of our kingly seal,
Suffer the death of traitors. Bear him hence.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Since I must needs be martyred grant me this,
That nobody may whip, or torture me,
Or hang me for a traitor.

sp.speaker: Morg
sp.p: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Somebody
sp.l: Or if needs I must die a traitor's death,
That nobody may see me when I die.

sp.speaker: Malg.
sp.p: Hence with the traitor.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I know by your complexion you were ripe for the hangman, but now to this lean gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Let me doom him, smooth spaniel, soothing groom
Slick oily knave, egregious parasite,
Thou turning vane, and changing weathercock,
My sentence is thou shalt be naked stripped,
And by the city beadles soundly whipped.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I'll make bold to see th'execution.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Well hath the King decreed, now by your highness' patience let nobody borrow a word or two of everybody.

div.head: The epilogue.
div.p: Here if you wonder why the King Elidurus bestows nothing on me for all my good services in his land, if the multitude should say he hath preferred nobody, somebody or other would say it were not well done, for in doing good to nobody he should but get himself an ill name. Therefore I will leave my suit to him, and turn to you. Kind gentleman if anybody here dislike nobody, than I hope everybody have pleased you, for being offended with nobody, nor anybody can find himself aggrieved, gentlemen they have a cold suit that have nobody to speak in their cause, and therefore blame us not to fear, yet our comfort is this, if nobody have offended you cannot blame nobody for it, or rather we will find somebody hereafter shall make good the fault that nobody hath done, and so I crave the general grace of everybody.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Now forward lords, long may our glories stand,
Three sundry times crowned King of this fair land.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
